name: Eldhraun - World's Largest Moss-Covered Lava Field
description: Eldhraun represents Earth's largest lava field created during single eruption event, covering approximately 565 square kilometers (220 square miles) of South Iceland landscape where catastrophic 1783-1784 Laki volcanic eruption produced 14 cubic kilometers (42 billion tonnes) of basaltic lava flows over eight-month period from June 1783 to February 1784, creating apocalyptic environmental disaster that transformed Icelandic society, caused global climate anomalies, contributed to French Revolution conditions through agricultural failures, and demonstrated volcanic eruptions' capacity to affect entire Northern Hemisphere through atmospheric aerosol injection. The Laki fissure eruption released 120 million tonnes of sulfur dioxide into atmosphere along with massive hydrofluoric acid clouds that poisoned Iceland's grasslands, killing approximately 50-80% of Iceland's livestock (including 50% of cattle, 80% of sheep) through fluorine poisoning as animals ingested contaminated vegetation, leading to famine killing roughly 20% of Iceland's human population (approximately 10,000 people from 50,000 total) in catastrophe remembered as Móðuharðindin (Mist Hardships) that nearly ended Icelandic settlement and prompted Danish government to consider evacuating surviving population to Danish territories. The global climate impacts created 'year without summer' conditions across Northern Hemisphere where sulfate aerosols formed stratospheric veil reducing solar radiation reaching Earth's surface.
address: Eldhraun, between Kirkjubæjarklaustur and Vík, South Iceland (along Route 1)
